poem:
**A Playwright's Paradox**

In the shadow of the quill's dance,  
Stoppard awoke to fame's embrace,  
where words twist like river's glance,  
contradictions in whispered grace.  
To argue time's relentless march,  
on stage, his restless thoughts unwind;  
truths reflected in a mirrored arch,  
the eloquence of a questioning mind.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Sir Tom Stoppard obituary After the first night of his play Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead at the National Theatre in London in 1967, Tom Stoppard awoke, like Lord Byron, and found himself famous. This new star in the playwriting firmament was a restless, questing bundle of contradictions. Stoppard wrote great theatre because, primarily, he wrote argumentative and witty dialogue. Writing plays, he said, was the only respectable way of contradicting oneself. His favourite line". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
